articles.title: Fon der Lajen: The Western Balkans are getting closer to the European market, time to invest in the region
articles.summary: President of the European Commission on a visit to the Western Balkans region.
articles.content:
TIRANA – The President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, stated at the opening of the EU-Western Balkans investment forum in Tirana that the Western Balkans is “firmly on the path to membership in the European Union” and urged investors that it is the right time to invest in the region. Speaking before leaders and business representatives from the region, von der Leyen emphasized that the benefits of European integration are already felt in the daily lives of citizens, citing as an example the accession to the single payment system SEPA, which has reduced transaction costs by up to six times. “This is concrete progress, not just on paper but also in practice,” said the President of the European Commission.

She noted that countries that have already joined the European Union have experienced “incredible economic growth,” which is also expected for the Western Balkans. “Consider the recent waves of accession to our Union. The Polish economy has tripled in less than three decades. In Croatia, unemployment has fallen from 17 percent to four percent in just over a decade. The same will happen across the Western Balkans, and I am not talking about some distant future. Your economies are already ready for rapid growth in the coming years,” said Ursula von der Leyen. According to her, the goal of the Growth Plan for the Western Balkans is to double the GDP of this region in the next decade through the opening of European markets, regulatory integration, and investments in priority sectors. “That is why my message to investors today is simple. Do not let this opportunity pass you by. It is time to invest in the Western Balkans,” noted the President of the EC. At the forum in Tirana alone, ten business contracts were signed, and 24 new projects worth over four billion euros are being considered.

She noted that two regional hubs connected to the European network of centers that enable companies and startups to develop, train, and test artificial intelligence models using the European Union’s “supercomputers” will be established in Serbia and North Macedonia. In practice, this means that local firms could develop artificial intelligence-based solutions using EU infrastructure, without the need to do everything in Brussels, Berlin, or Paris. Ursula von der Leyen also highlighted the importance of the Western Balkans in producing ecological “clean energy,” stating that the region can become a hub for the production, storage, and sharing of such energy with the rest of Europe, as published on the European Commission’s website. “You are building a new energy backbone not only for the Western Balkans but for all of Europe,” she added. In addition, the President of the Commission emphasized the importance of integrating regional industries into European value chains – from batteries and pharmaceutical production to the textile recycling sector. “Investing in the Western Balkans means investing in a future European market of 500 million people,” concluded von der Leyen. (October 13)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on significant economic and regional integration progress for the Western Balkans with tangible benefits such as market access, investment opportunities, AI infrastructure development, and clean energy initiatives. These developments promise broad economic growth and improved living standards for millions, representing a meaningful positive change with substantial context and details.
articles.personality_title: Western Balkans move closer to EU market with new investment opportunities
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Western Balkans region is working to join the European Union (EU), aiming to improve its economy and connect more closely with Europe.

**What happened** – Ursula von der Leyen, President of the European Commission, visited Tirana and spoke at an EU-Western Balkans investment forum. She said the region is making real progress toward joining the EU and encouraged investors to put money into the area now. At the forum, ten business deals were signed, and 24 new projects worth over four billion euros are being planned. Two centers for developing artificial intelligence (AI) will be set up in Serbia and North Macedonia, giving local companies access to EU technology. She also highlighted the region’s role in producing clean energy for Europe.

**Impact** – Joining the EU market could help the Western Balkans grow faster like countries such as Poland and Croatia did after joining. Using the EU’s payment system has already made money transfers cheaper in the region. The new AI centers will allow local businesses to create advanced technology without needing to go to big European cities. Clean energy projects can make the area a key part of Europe's energy supply. These changes can improve jobs, technology, and energy for millions of people.

**What's next step** – The Western Balkans will continue working on joining the EU and building links with European industries like battery making and recycling. Investors are expected to support new projects, helping the region’s economy grow. The new AI hubs will soon open, and more clean energy plans will develop, moving the region closer to full EU integration.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Western Balkans are gaining stronger ties with the EU through new investments, technology centers, and clean energy projects, setting the stage for fast economic growth and closer European integration.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les Balkans occidentaux se rapprochent du marché européen avec de nouvelles opportunités d'investissement
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La région des Balkans occidentaux travaille à rejoindre l'Union européenne (UE), avec pour objectif d'améliorer son économie et de se connecter davantage à l'Europe.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Ursula von der Leyen, présidente de la Commission européenne, s'est rendue à Tirana et a pris la parole lors d'un forum d'investissement UE-Balkans occidentaux. Elle a déclaré que la région progresse réellement vers l'adhésion à l'UE et a encouragé les investisseurs à investir dès maintenant. Lors du forum, dix accords commerciaux ont été signés, et 24 nouveaux projets d'une valeur de plus de quatre milliards d'euros sont en cours de planification. Deux centres de développement de l'intelligence artificielle (IA) seront créés en Serbie et en Macédoine du Nord, donnant aux entreprises locales accès à la technologie de l'UE. Elle a également souligné le rôle de la région dans la production d'énergie propre pour l'Europe.

**Impact** – Rejoindre le marché de l'UE pourrait aider les Balkans occidentaux à croître rapidement, comme l'ont fait la Pologne et la Croatie après leur adhésion. L'utilisation du système de paiement européen a déjà réduit le coût des transferts d'argent dans la région. Les nouveaux centres d'IA permettront aux entreprises locales de créer des technologies avancées sans devoir se rendre dans les grandes villes européennes. Les projets d'énergie propre peuvent faire de la région un acteur clé de l'approvisionnement énergétique européen. Ces changements peuvent améliorer l'emploi, la technologie et l'énergie pour des millions de personnes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les Balkans occidentaux continueront de travailler à leur adhésion à l'UE et au renforcement de leurs liens avec les industries européennes telles que la fabrication de batteries et le recyclage. Les investisseurs devraient soutenir les nouveaux projets, aidant ainsi la croissance économique de la région. Les nouveaux centres d'IA ouvriront bientôt, et davantage de projets d'énergie propre seront développés, rapprochant la région d'une intégration complète à l'UE.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les Balkans occidentaux renforcent leurs liens avec l'UE grâce à de nouveaux investissements, centres technologiques et projets d'énergie propre, ouvrant la voie à une croissance économique rapide et une intégration européenne plus étroite.
articles.personality_title_es: Los Balcanes occidentales se acercan al mercado europeo con nuevas oportunidades de inversión
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La región de los Balcanes occidentales está trabajando para unirse a la Unión Europea (UE), con el objetivo de mejorar su economía y conectarse más con Europa.

**Qué pasó** – Ursula von der Leyen, presidenta de la Comisión Europea, visitó Tirana y habló en un foro de inversión UE-Balcanes occidentales. Dijo que la región está avanzando hacia la adhesión a la UE y animó a los inversores a invertir ahora. En el foro, se firmaron diez acuerdos comerciales y se están planificando 24 nuevos proyectos por valor de más de cuatro mil millones de euros. Se establecerán dos centros para desarrollar inteligencia artificial (IA) en Serbia y Macedonia del Norte, dando a las empresas locales acceso a tecnología de la UE. También destacó el papel de la región en la producción de energía limpia para Europa.

**Impacto** – Unirse al mercado de la UE podría ayudar a los Balcanes occidentales a crecer rápido, como hicieron Polonia y Croacia después de unirse. Usar el sistema de pagos de la UE ya ha hecho que las transferencias de dinero sean más baratas en la región. Los nuevos centros de IA permitirán a las empresas locales crear tecnología avanzada sin tener que ir a las grandes ciudades europeas. Los proyectos de energía limpia pueden convertir a la región en un punto clave del suministro energético europeo. Estos cambios pueden mejorar el empleo, la tecnología y la energía para millones de personas.

**Próximo paso** – Los Balcanes occidentales seguirán trabajando para unirse a la UE y fortalecer sus vínculos con industrias europeas como la fabricación de baterías y el reciclaje. Se espera que los inversores apoyen nuevos proyectos, ayudando a crecer la economía regional. Los nuevos centros de IA abrirán pronto y se desarrollarán más planes de energía limpia, acercando la región a la integración completa en la UE.

**Frase clave** – Los Balcanes occidentales fortalecen sus lazos con la UE mediante nuevas inversiones, centros tecnológicos y proyectos de energía limpia, preparando el camino para un rápido crecimiento económico y una integración europea más cercana.
